posts.name: James
posts.cooked: For some context: I have been involved in first for 8+ years and just finished my first year of FRC . I would consider myself a dedicated team member, and have good all around knowledge in mechanics, but none in programming. Over this summer, I am striving to learn Java (focused around FRC ) to help increase my understanding of the bot and how to make it better in all aspects. I have been supplied with a XRP by my coach and some other recourses and links. Just wondering what tips and advice the community would have for me.

posts.name: Yishai Levy
posts.cooked: The Java Koans by team 3550 is a pretty nice way to get the hang of Java, would definitely recommend.

link_counts.title: Team 3550 presents: FRC Java koans for teaching Java to rookie students

posts.name: Ty Galle
posts.cooked: GPT-4o/Programming GPT’s know and, I believe, understand the wpilib library. So, if you hit a niche problem or need a second opinion on code and no one is available, you can ask ChatGPT. (Keep in mind GPT-4o has token limits that refresh over time) Also, don’t believe everything it says due to AI’s proneness to hallucinating.

posts.name: Ty Galle
posts.cooked: Ok, I was just testing the Java GPT I was using. It just taught me about how arcade drive is. I would highly recommend, if you’re trying to fill in any gaps in your knowledge.

posts.name: Amit sucher
posts.cooked: Also if you are looking something more towards frc I made a gpt that has a tonnn of knowledge about frc proggraming from many sources, it might be a better fit but I am not 100% sure
